  "article_text": [
    "skein modules were independently introduced in 1987 by przytycki @xcite and turaev @xcite . they generalize knot polynomials in @xmath5 to knot polynomials in arbitrary 3-manifolds .",
    "the essence is that skein modules are quotients of free modules over ambient isotopy classes of links in 3-manifolds by properly chosen local ( skein ) relations .",
    "let @xmath6 be an oriented @xmath7-manifold , @xmath8 $ ] , @xmath9 the set of all oriented links in @xmath6 up to ambient isotopy in @xmath6 and let @xmath10 be the submodule of @xmath11 generated by the skein expressions @xmath12 , where @xmath13 , @xmath14 and @xmath15 comprise a conway triple represented schematically by the illustrations in figure  [ skein ] .",
    "locally.,width=163 ]    for convenience we allow the empty knot , @xmath16 , and add the relation @xmath17 , where @xmath18 denotes the trivial knot . then the _ homflypt skein module _ of @xmath6 is defined to be :    @xmath19,u^{-1 } l_{+ } -ul_{- } -zl{}_{0 } \\right)={\\raise0.7ex\\hbox{$ r\\mathcal{l } $ } \\!\\mathord{\\left/ { \\vphantom { r\\mathcal{l } s } } \\right . \\kern-\\nulldelimiterspace}\\!\\lower0.7ex\\hbox{$",
    "s   $ } } .\\ ] ]    skein modules of @xmath7-manifolds have become very important algebraic tools in the study of @xmath7-manifolds , since their properties renders topological information about the @xmath7-manifolds . unlike the kauffman bracket skein module , the homflypt skein module of a @xmath7-manifold , also known as _ conway skein module _ and as _ third skein module _ , is very hard to compute and very little is known so far .",
    "more precisely , @xmath20 $ ] , where the empty link is a generator of the module ( @xcite , @xcite ) .",
    "also , for the solid torus st , @xmath3 is a free , infinitely generated @xmath21$]-module isomorphic to the symmetric tensor algebra @xmath22 , where @xmath23 denotes the conjugacy classes of non trivial elements of @xmath24 ( @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite ) .",
    "further , let @xmath25 denote a surface .",
    "then @xmath26 is an algebra which , as an @xmath27 module , is a free module isomorphic to the symmetric tensor algebra , @xmath28 , where @xmath29 denotes the conjugacy classes of nontrivial elements of @xmath30 ( @xcite ) .",
    "moreover , @xmath31 is freely generated by standard oriented unlinks as presented in figure  [ mroc ] ( @xcite ) and @xmath32 is freely generated by the empty link over a properly chosen ring ( @xcite ) .",
    "finally , @xmath33 is isomorphic to @xmath34 modulo torsion , where @xmath35 are oriented 3-manifolds and @xmath36 their connected sum ( @xcite ) .    in @xcite the homflypt skein module of the lens spaces @xmath0",
    "is computed using diagrammatic method .",
    "the diagrammatic method could in theory be generalized to the case of @xmath37 , but the diagrams become even more complex to analyze and several induction arguments fail .",
    ".,width=124 ]    in @xcite the most generic analogue of the homflypt polynomial , @xmath2 , for links in the solid torus @xmath38 has been derived from the generalized hecke algebras of type @xmath39 , @xmath40 , via a unique markov trace constructed on them .",
    "this algebra was defined by lambropoulou in @xcite and is related to the knot theory of the solid torus , the artin group of coxeter group of type b , @xmath41 , and to the affine hecke algebra of type a. the lambropoulou invariant @xmath2 recovers the homflypt skein module of st , @xmath3 , and is appropriate for extending the results to the lens spaces @xmath42 , since the combinatorial setting is the same as for @xmath38 , only the braid equivalence includes the braid band moves ( shorthanded to _ bbm _ ) , which reflect the surgery description of @xmath42 . for the case of @xmath0 , in order to extend @xmath2 to an invariant of links in @xmath0 we need to solve an infinite system of equations resulting from the braid band moves . namely we force :    @xmath43    for all @xmath44 and for all possible slidings of @xmath45 .",
    "the above equations have particularly simple formulations with the use of a new basis , @xmath4 , for the homflypt skein module of @xmath38 , that we give in @xcite .",
    "this basis was predicted by przytycki and is crucial in this paper , since _ bbm _",
    "s are naturally described by elements in this basis .    in order to show that the set @xmath4 is a basis for @xmath46",
    ", we started in @xcite with the well - known basis of @xmath46 , @xmath47 , discovered independently in @xcite and @xcite with diagrammatic methods , and a basis @xmath48 of the algebra @xmath40 and we followed the steps below :    * an ordering relation in @xmath47 is defined and it is shown that the set is totally ordered .",
    "* elements in @xmath47 are converted to linear combinations of elements in the new set @xmath4 as follows : * elements in @xmath47 are first converted to elements in the linear basis of @xmath49 , @xmath48 . * using conjugation , the gaps appearing in the indices of the looping generators in the monomials in @xmath50 are managed . * using conjugation , the exponents of the looping generators are ordered . * using conjugation and stabilization moves , the ` braiding tails ' are removed from the above monomials and thus , the initial elements in @xmath50 are converted to linear combination of elements in @xmath4 .",
    "* finally , the sets @xmath47 and @xmath4 are related via a block diagonal matrix , where each block is an infinite lower triangular matrix . *",
    "the diagonal elements in the above matrix are invertible , making the matrix invertible and thus , the set @xmath4 is a basis for @xmath46 .",
    "the new basis is appropriate for computing the homflypt skein module of the lens spaces @xmath42 in general .",
    "note that @xmath46 plays an important role in the study of homflypt skein modules of arbitrary c.c.o .",
    "@xmath7-manifolds , since every c.c.o .",
    "@xmath7-manifold can be obtained by surgery along a framed link in @xmath5 with unknotted components .",
    "the family of the lens spaces , @xmath42 , comprises the simplest example , since they are obtained by rational surgery on the unknot .",
    "equations  ( [ eqbbm ] ) are very controlled in the algebraic setting , because , as shown in @xcite , they can be performed only on elements in @xmath4 .",
    "this is shown by following the technique developed in @xcite .",
    "the difference lies in the fact that here we deal with elements in @xmath4 and at the same time with their result after the performance of a _ bbm _ and we keep track of how _ bbm _",
    "s affect the steps described above .",
    "more precisely , in @xcite we followed the steps below :    * equations  ( [ eqbbm ] ) boil down by linearity to considering only words in the canonical basis @xmath51 of the algebra @xmath52 . * for words in @xmath53 equations of the form @xmath54",
    "are obtained , where @xmath55 is the result of the performance of a braid band move on the _ first _ moving strand of the closed braid @xmath56 , and @xmath57 .",
    "* then , elements in @xmath53 are expressed to elements in the linear basis @xmath48 of @xmath52 and it is shown that the equations for words in @xmath53 are equivalent to equations of the form @xmath58 , where @xmath59 . * a set @xmath60",
    "is then introduced , consisting of monomials in the looping generators @xmath61 s with no gaps in the indices ( as in @xmath4 ) but not necessarily ordered exponents . * equations for words in @xmath50",
    "are now reduced to equations obtained from elements in the @xmath52-module @xmath60 , where the braid band moves are performed on _ any moving strand_. * equations of the form @xmath62 are now obtained , where @xmath63 is the result of the performance of a braid band move on the @xmath64 moving strand of the closed braid @xmath65 , and @xmath66 an element in the augmented set @xmath60 followed by a ` braiding tail ' . * using conjugation ,",
    "the exponents then become in decreasing order and equations obtained from elements in the @xmath52-module @xmath60 by performing _",
    "s on all moving strands are reduced to equations for words in @xmath52-module @xmath4 by performing _",
    "s on all moving strands . *",
    "the ` braiding tails ' from elements in the @xmath52-module @xmath4 are now eliminated and it is shown that equations for words in the @xmath52-module @xmath4 by performing braid band moves on any strand , are now reduced to equations obtained from elements in the basis @xmath4 of @xmath3 by performing braid band moves on every moving strand :    @xmath67    in @xcite we elaborate on the infinite system .",
    "the importance of our approach is that it can shed light on the problem of computing skein modules of arbitrary c.c.o .",
    "@xmath7-manifolds , since any @xmath7-manifold can be obtained by surgery on @xmath5 along unknotted closed curves .",
    "indeed , one can use our results in order to apply a braid approach to the skein module of an arbitrary c.c.o .",
    "the main difficulty of the problem lies in selecting from the infinitum of band moves ( or handle slide moves ) some basic ones , solving the infinite system of equations and proving that there are no dependencies in the solutions .",
    "note that the computation of @xmath1 is equivalent to constructing all possible analogues of the homflypt or 2-variable jones polynomial for knots and links in @xmath0 , since the linear dimension of @xmath1 means the number of independent homflypt - type invariants defined on knots and links in @xmath0 .",
    "the paper is organized as follows : in  [ basics ] we recall the setting and the essential techniques and results from @xcite .",
    "more precisely , we describe braid equivalence for knots and links in @xmath0 and we present a sharpened version of the reidemeister theorem for links in @xmath0 .",
    "we also provide geometric formulations of the braid equivalence via mixed braids in @xmath5 using the @xmath68-moves and the braid band moves and give algebraic formulations in terms of the mixed braid groups @xmath69 . in  [ solidtorus ] we present results from @xcite and @xcite .",
    "more precisely , we recover the homflypt skein module of the solid torus st , @xmath3 , via algebraic techniques and we present a new basis for @xmath3 , @xmath4 , from which the braid band moves are naturally described .",
    "the aim of this section is to set a homogeneous ground in computing skein modules of c.c.o .",
    "@xmath7-manifolds in general via algebraic means . in ",
    "3 we derive the relation between @xmath3 and @xmath1 and show that in order to compute @xmath1 we only need to consider elements in the basis @xmath4 of @xmath3 and impose on the lambropoulou invariant @xmath2 relations coming by performing all possible braid band moves on elements in @xmath4 .",
    "we consider st to be the complement of a solid torus in @xmath5 .",
    "then , an oriented link @xmath68 in st can be represented by an oriented _ mixed link _ in @xmath70 , that is , a link in @xmath70 consisting of the unknotted _ fixed part _",
    "@xmath71 representing the complementary solid torus in @xmath5 and the _ moving part _",
    "@xmath68 that links with @xmath71 .",
    "mixed link diagram _ is a diagram @xmath72 of @xmath73 on the plane of @xmath71 , where this plane is equipped with the top - to - bottom direction of @xmath74 ( see @xcite ) .",
    ".,width=105 ]    it is well  known that the lens spaces @xmath0 can be obtained from @xmath5 by surgery on the unknot with surgery coefficient @xmath75 .",
    "surgery along the unknot can be realized by considering first the complementary solid torus and then attaching to it a solid torus according to some homeomorphism on the boundary .",
    "thus , isotopy in @xmath0 can be viewed as isotopy in st together with the _ band moves _ in @xmath5 , which reflect the surgery description of the manifold , see figure  [ bmov ] ( see @xcite ) . in @xcite",
    "we show that in order to describe isotopy for knots and links in a c.c.o .",
    "@xmath7-manifold , it suffices to consider only the type @xmath45 band moves ( see figure  [ unknsurg ] ) and thus , isotopy between oriented links in @xmath0 is reflected in @xmath5 by means of the following result ( cf .",

    "-moves , width=470 ]    in order to translate isotopy for links in @xmath0 into mixed braid equivalence , we first define a _ braid band move _ to be a move between mixed braids , which is a type @xmath45 band move between their closures .",
    "it starts with a little band oriented downward , which , before sliding along a surgery strand , gets one twist _",
    "positive _ or _ negative _ ( see figure  [ bbm12 ] ) .",
    "then , isotopy in @xmath0 is translated on the level of mixed braids by means of the following theorem :    ( * ? ? ?",

    "we denote a braid band move by _ bbm _ and , specifically , the result of a positive or negative braid band move performed on the @xmath64-moving strand of a mixed braid @xmath66 by @xmath109 .",
    "note that in the statement of theorem  [ markov ] in @xcite the braid band moves take place on the last strand of a mixed braid .",
    "clearly , this is equivalent to performing the braid band moves on the first moving strand or , in fact , on any specified moving strand of the mixed braid .",
    "indeed , in a mixed braid @xmath110 consider the last moving strand of @xmath66 approaching the surgery strand @xmath74 from the right . before performing a _ bbm",
    "_ we apply conjugation ( isotopy in st ) and we obtain an equivalent mixed braid where the first strand is now approaching @xmath74 ( see figure  [ bbmconj ] ) . in terms of diagrams",

    "setting of @xcite , the elements of @xmath3 correspond bijectively to the elements of the following set @xmath47 :    @xmath161",
    "so , we have that @xmath47 is a basis of @xmath3 in terms of braids .",
    "note that @xmath47 is a subset of @xmath162 and , in particular , @xmath47 is a subset of @xmath163 .",
    "note also that in contrast to elements in @xmath163 , the elements in @xmath47 have no gaps in the indices , the exponents are ordered and there are no ` braiding tails ' .",
    "the lambropoulou invariant @xmath2 recovers @xmath3 , because it gives distinct values to distinct elements of @xmath47 , since @xmath164 .",

    "namely , if @xmath166 denotes the unknot , then @xmath167 and @xmath168 .      in @xcite we give a different basis @xmath4 for @xmath3 , which was predicted by j. przytycki and which is described in eq .",
    "[ basis ] in open braid form .",
    "* theorem  2)[newbasis ] the following set is a @xmath169$]-basis for @xmath3 : @xmath170    the importance of the new basis @xmath4 of @xmath3 lies in the simplicity of the algebraic expression of a braid band move , which extends the link isotopy in st to link isotopy in @xmath0 and this fact was our motivation for establishing this new basis @xmath4 ( recall theorem  1(iv ) , remark  [ tprt ] and figure  [ bbm12 ] ) .",
    ".,width=153 ]    .,width=124 ]    notice that comparing the set @xmath4 with the set @xmath171 , we observe that there are no gaps in the indices of the @xmath61 s and the exponents are in decreasing order .",
    "also , there are no ` braiding tails ' in the words in @xmath4 .    our method for proving theorem  [ newbasis ]",
    "is the following :    @xmath172 we define total orderings in the sets @xmath47 and @xmath4 ,    @xmath172 we show that the two ordered sets are related via a lower triangular infinite matrix with invertible elements on the diagonal , and    @xmath172 using this matrix , we show that the set @xmath4 is linearly independent .    in order to relate the two sets via a lower triangular infinite matrix",
    "we start with elements in the basic set @xmath47 and we first convert them into sums of elements in @xmath171 , containing the linear bases of the algebras @xmath49 .",
    "these elements consist of two parts : arbitrary monomials in the @xmath61 s followed by ` braiding tails ' in the bases of the algebras @xmath146 .",
    "then , these elements are converted into elements in the set @xmath4 by :    * managing the gaps in the indices , * by ordering the exponents of the @xmath61 s and * by eliminating the ` braiding tails ' .",
    "it is worth mentioning that these procedures are not independent in the sense that when , for example one manages the gaps in the indices of the looping generators @xmath61 s , ` braiding tails ' may occur and also the exponents of the @xmath61 s may alter . similarly , when the ` braiding tails ' are eliminated , gaps in the indices of the @xmath61 s might occur .",
    "this is a long procedure that eventually stops and only elements in the set @xmath4 remain .      for defining orderings in the sets @xmath174 and @xmath47",
    "we need the notion of the _ index _ of a word @xmath175 in any of these sets , denoted @xmath176 . in @xmath47 or @xmath4 @xmath176",
    "is defined to be the highest index of the @xmath86 s , resp . of the @xmath61 s in @xmath175 .",
    "similarly , in @xmath163 or @xmath171 , @xmath176 is defined as above by ignoring possible gaps in the indices of the looping generators and by ignoring the braiding parts in the algebras @xmath125 . moreover , the index of a monomial in @xmath125 is equal to @xmath177 .",
    "@xmath178    we now proceed with defining an ordering relation in the sets @xmath171 and @xmath163 , which passes to their respective subsets @xmath4 and @xmath47 :    ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition  2 ) [ order ] let @xmath179 and @xmath180 in @xmath163 , where @xmath181 for all @xmath182 and @xmath183 . then , we define the following ordering in @xmath163 :    * if @xmath184 , then @xmath185 . * if @xmath186 , then : + \\(i ) if @xmath187 , then @xmath185 , + \\(ii ) if @xmath188 , then : +  ( @xmath45 ) if @xmath189 , then @xmath190 , +   ( @xmath66 ) if @xmath191 for all @xmath80 and @xmath192 , then @xmath185 , +   ( @xmath193 ) if @xmath191 for all @xmath80 and @xmath194 and @xmath195 , then @xmath185 , +  ( @xmath196 ) if @xmath197 and @xmath198 , @xmath199 , then @xmath200 .",
    "the ordering in the set @xmath171 is defined as in @xmath163 , where @xmath86 s are replaced by @xmath61 s .",
    "@xmath201    in order to eventually get to the infinite matrix relating the two basic sets @xmath47 and @xmath4 we need to define the _ subsets of level @xmath202 _ , @xmath203 and @xmath204 , of @xmath4 and @xmath47 respectively ( ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition  3 ) ) , to be the sets :    @xmath205    in @xcite it was shown that the sets @xmath203 and @xmath204 are totally ordered and well ordered for all @xmath202 ( ( * ? ? ?",
    "* propositions  1 & 2 ) ) .",
    "note that the sets @xmath4 and @xmath47 admit a natural grading : @xmath206 and @xmath207 .    in the rest of the section we will be using the ordering in the transitions from @xmath163 to @xmath171 and from @xmath171 to @xmath4 .",
    "in this subsection we convert monomials in the @xmath135 s to expressions containing the @xmath61 s .",
    "full details and related technical lemmas are provided in @xcite . in order to simplify the expressions in this step",
    "we first introduce the following notation .",
    "[ nt ] we set @xmath208 and @xmath209 , for @xmath210 , @xmath211 for all @xmath212 .",
    "we now introduce the notion of _ homologous words _ , which is crucial for relating the sets @xmath47 and @xmath4 via a triangular matrix .",
    "* definition  4 ) we say that two words @xmath213 and @xmath214 are _ homologous _ , denoted @xmath215 , if @xmath175 is obtained from @xmath216 by changing @xmath135 into @xmath61 for all @xmath217 .",
    "the words @xmath218 and @xmath219 are homologous .",
    "note also that @xmath220 .    in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma  11 ) it is shown that the following relations hold in @xmath52 for @xmath221 :    @xmath222    where @xmath223 , @xmath224 and @xmath225 , if @xmath226 and @xmath227 , if @xmath228 .",
    "using now these relations , we have that every element in @xmath47 can be expressed as a linear sum of each homologous word , the homologous word with ` braiding tails ' and elements in @xmath171 of lower order , as illustrated abstractly in figure  [ fthm7 ] .",

    ".,width=384 ]    [ eg1]we shall now give examples of monomials in @xmath47 converted into sums of elements in @xmath171 using technical lemmas from @xcite ( ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemmas  3 , 4 , 5 , 6 , 9 & 11 ) ) .",
    "the examples provide at the same time the motivation for the subsections that follow .",
    "* consider the monomial @xmath236 .",
    "we have that : + @xmath237\\ + \\\\ & & \\\\ & + & tt_1^{-1}\\cdot \\left [ ( q-1)(q^2-q+1)\\cdot g_2^{-1}- ( q-1)^2\\cdot g_1g_2g_1^{-1}g_2^{-1 } \\right]+\\\\ & & \\\\ & + & tt_2^{-1}\\cdot \\left[q^2(q-1)\\cdot g_2^{-1}+q(q-1)^3\\cdot g_2^{-1}-q(q-1)^2\\cdot g_2g_1^{-1}g_2^{-1 } \\right]+\\\\ & & \\\\ & + & t_1t_2^{-1}\\cdot \\left [ q(q-1)\\cdot g_2g_1^{-1}g_2^{-1}-q(q-1)^2\\cdot g_1^{-1}g_2^{-1 } \\right]+\\\\ & & \\\\ & + & t^{-1}t_1 \\cdot \\left[-(q-1)\\cdot g_2g_1^{-1}g_2^{-1 } - q^{-1}(q-1)^2\\cdot g_1^{-1}g_2^{-1 } \\right ] \\end{array}\\ ] ] + so , we obtain the homologous word @xmath238 , the word @xmath175 again followed by the braiding element @xmath239 and terms in @xmath171 of order less than @xmath175 : since either their index is less that @xmath176 ( the terms @xmath240 , @xmath241 and @xmath242 ) , or they contain gaps in the indices ( the terms @xmath243 and @xmath244 ) . * a simpler example is the following : @xmath245 + we obtained the homologous word @xmath246 , the element @xmath247 in @xmath171 comprising the monomial @xmath248 with gaps in the indices , followed by ` braiding tail ' @xmath239 and also the lower order term @xmath249 in the @xmath133-module @xmath4 .    in theorem",
    "[ convert ] note that in the right hand side there are terms which do not belong to the set @xmath4 .",
    "the point now is that these terms are elements in the set of bases @xmath171 on the hecke algebras @xmath49 , but , when we are working in @xmath3 , which is the knots and links level , such elements must be considered up to conjugation by any generator of the alegbra and up to stabilization moves ( recall theorem  [ markov ] ) .",
    "topologically , conjugation corresponds to closing a mixed braid .      in this subsection",
    "we show how to deal with monomials in @xmath171 where the looping elements do not have consecutive indices .",
    "we call _ gaps _ in monomials of the @xmath61 s any gaps occurring in the indices . after managing , that is eliminating ,",
    "the gaps we pass to the augmented @xmath146-module @xmath60 , which consists of monomials in the @xmath61 s with consecutive indices but not necessarily ordered exponents .",
    "* definition  3)[expsetl ] we define the sets : @xmath250 and the _ subset of level @xmath202 _ of @xmath60 @xmath251 : @xmath252    note that in @xcite the set @xmath60 is denoted by @xmath68 .",
    "obviously the set @xmath4 ( eq .",
    "10 ) is a subset of @xmath60 .",
    "whenever we talk about a module with coefficients in @xmath253 we shall be denoting it by @xmath146-module .    in what follows for the expressions that we obtain after appropriate conjugations we shall use the notation @xmath254 .",
    "* theorem  8)[gp ] let @xmath255 be a monomial in the @xmath61 s with gaps in the indices .",
    "then we have that :    @xmath256    where @xmath257 and @xmath258 for some @xmath259 and for all @xmath217 .",
    "theorem  [ gp ] is best demonstrated in the following example on a word with two gaps .",
    "note that we underline expressions which are crucial for the next step .",
    "for the 2-gap word @xmath260 we have : @xmath261 \\ t_6^{-1}g_3 ^ 2g_5g_4 & = \\\\ & & & & & \\\\ & = & q^2t^{k_0}t_1^{k_1}t_2t_3 ^ 2\\underline{g_4g_5t_6^{-1}}g_3 ^ 2g_5g_4 & + & q(q-1)t^{k_0}t_1^{k_1}t_2t_3t_4\\underline{g_5t_6^{-1}}g_3 ^ 2g_5g_4 & + \\\\ & & & & & \\\\ &   & & + & ( q-1)t^{k_0}t_1^{k_1}t_2t_3t_5\\underline{g_4t_6^{-1}}g_3 ^ 2g_5g_4 & = \\\\ & & & & & \\\\   & = & q^2t^{k_0}t_1^{k_1}t_2t_3 ^ 2\\underline{t_6^{-1}}g_4g_5g_3 ^ 2g_5g_4 & + & ( q-1)t^{k_0}t_1^{k_1}t_2t_3\\underline{t_5}t_6^{-1}g_4g_3 ^ 2g_5g_4 & + \\\\ & & & & & \\\\   & &   & + & q(q-1)t^{k_0}t_1^{k_1}t_2t_3t_4\\underline{t_6^{-1}}g_5g_3 ^ 2g_5g_4 & \\widehat{=}\\\\ \\end{array}\\ ] ]    @xmath262      by theorem  [ gp ] we have to deal with elements in @xmath60 , where the looping generators have consecutive indices but their exponents are not in decreasing order , followed by ` braiding tails ' . we show that these elements are conjugate equivalent to sums of elements in the @xmath263-module @xmath4 , namely , elements in @xmath4 followed by ` braiding tails ' .",
    "* theorem  9)[exp ] for an element in the @xmath146-module @xmath60 we have that :    @xmath264    where @xmath265 and @xmath266 for all @xmath212 .",
    "consider the element @xmath267 and apply theorem  [ exp ] on the first ` bad ' exponent occurring in the word , starting from right to left . in that way we obtain a word with one less ` bad ' exponent , so applying theorem  [ exp ] again we obtain elements in the set @xmath4 followed by braiding tails .",
    "more precisely : @xmath268 where @xmath269 , for all @xmath217 and @xmath270 $ ] .",
    "so far we have seen how to convert elements in the basis @xmath47 to sums of elements in @xmath171 and then , using conjugation , how these elements are expressed as sums of elements in the @xmath263-module @xmath4 .",
    "we now present results on how using conjugation and stabilization moves all these elements in the @xmath263-module @xmath4 are expressed as sums of elements in the set @xmath4 with scalars in the field @xmath271 .",
    "we will use the symbol @xmath272 when a stabilization move is performed and @xmath273 when both stabilization moves and conjugation are used .",
    "more precisely , in @xcite we prove the following :    ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  10 ) [ tails ] for a word in the @xmath146-module , @xmath4 we have :    @xmath274    such that @xmath275 , @xmath276 and @xmath277 for all @xmath212 .    in this example",
    "we demonstrate how to eliminate the ` braiding tail ' in a word .",
    "@xmath278    we have that : @xmath279    and so @xmath280    [ rm4]this is a long procedure , since eliminating the tails will give rise to gaps in the indices again .",
    "recall however that when managing gaps in the indices and ordering the exponents of the @xmath61 s we also obtain ` braiding tails ' .",
    "this is a long procedure which , as shown in @xcite using complex and technical inductions , this procedure eventually terminates and only elements in @xmath4 remain .",
    "this means that @xmath4 is a generating set for @xmath3 .",
    "this procedure is abstractly demonstrated in figure  [ alg ] . in the figure",
    ", we start with a word @xmath85 in the old basis of @xmath3 , @xmath47 , and applying theorems  810 we end up with a linear combination of the homologous word @xmath281 and of elements @xmath282 smaller than @xmath255 .     to @xmath4.,width=499 ]      with the orderings given in definition  [ order ] , in @xcite we showed that the infinite matrix converting elements of the basis @xmath47 of @xmath3 to elements of the set @xmath4 is a block diagonal matrix , where each block corresponds to a subset of @xmath47 of level @xmath202 and it is an infinite lower triangular matrix with invertible elements in the diagonal .",
    "this constitutes our strategy for proving theorem  [ newbasis ] .",
    "more precisely , fixing the level @xmath202 of a subset of @xmath47 , the proof of theorem  [ newbasis ] is based on the following :    * a monomial @xmath283 can be expressed as linear combinations of elements in @xmath284 , @xmath285 , followed by monomials in @xmath263 , with scalars in @xmath271 such that there exists @xmath286 . * applying conjugation and stabilization moves on all @xmath285 s results in elements @xmath287 in @xmath203 , such that @xmath288 for all @xmath217 . *",
    "the coefficient of @xmath175 is an invertible element in @xmath271 .",
    "* @xmath289 .",
    "* using this infinite diagonal matrix , in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  11 ) we showed that the set @xmath4 is linearly independent . hence , using the above and remark  [ rm4 ] , @xmath4 forms a basis for the homflypt skein module of st .",
    "we now return to our initial aim , that is , the computation of the homflypt skein module of a lens space @xmath0 .",
    "as explained in the introduction , in order to compute @xmath291 we need to normalize the invariant @xmath2 ( recall theorem  5 ) by forcing it to satisfy all possible braid band moves ( _ bbm _ ) , recall eq .  1 .",
    "at this point the reader should recall the discussion in the introduction culminating to equation  2 . in order to simplify this system of equations , in @xcite",
    "we first show that performing a _ bbm _ on a mixed braid in @xmath41 reduces to performing _",
    "s on elements in the canonical basis , @xmath134 , of the algebra @xmath52 and , in fact , on their first moving strand .",
    "we then reduce the equations obtained from elements in @xmath163 to equations obtained from elements in @xmath171 . in order now to reduce further the computation to elements in the basis @xmath4 of @xmath3 , we first recall that elements in @xmath171 consist in two parts : a monomial in @xmath61 s with possible gaps in the indices and unordered exponents , followed by a ` braiding tail ' in the basis of @xmath146 .",
    "so , we first manage the gaps in the indices of the looping generators of elements in @xmath171 , obtaining elements in the augmented @xmath133-module @xmath60 ( followed by ` braiding tails ' ) .",
    "note that the performance of _ bbm _ s is now considered to take place on any moving strand .",
    "we then show that the equations obtained from elements in the @xmath133-module @xmath60 by performing _",
    "_ s on any strand are equivalent to equations obtained from elements in the @xmath133-module @xmath4 by performing _ bbm",
    "_ s on any strand ( ordering the exponenets in the @xmath61 s ) .",
    "we finally eliminate the ` braiding tails ' from elements in the @xmath133-module @xmath4 and reduce the computations to the set @xmath4 , where the _ bbm _ s are performed on any moving strand ( see @xcite ) .",
    "thus , in order to compute @xmath291 , it suffices to solve the infinite system of equations obtained by performing _ bbm _",
    "s on any moving strand of elements in the set @xmath4 .    in this section",
    "we present the above steps in more details .",
    "the procedure is similar to the one described in @xcite ( see   2 in this paper ) , but now we do it simultaneously before and after the performance of a braid band move .      we now show that it suffices to perform _ bbm _",
    "s on elements in the linear basis of @xmath52 , @xmath163 . as already mentioned , this is the first step in order to restrict the performance of _ bbm _ s only on elements in the basis @xmath4 .",
    "we first recall that by the artin combing we can write words in @xmath41 in the form @xmath84 , where @xmath85 is a monomial in the @xmath86 s and @xmath87 ( remark  1 ) .",
    "we then note the following :    [ artcomb ] braid band moves are interchangeable with the artin combing .",
    "let @xmath292 . then",
    ", the proof is clear from the following diagram : @xmath293    ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma  2)[lbbmskein ] braid band moves and the quadratic relation ( skein relation ) are interchangeable .    by lemma  [ artcomb ] , a word in @xmath41 can be assumed in the form @xmath294 , where @xmath295 is a monomial in @xmath86 s and @xmath296 .",
    "seen as a monomial in @xmath146 and applying the quadratic relation , the element @xmath175 can be written as a sum : @xmath297 , where the @xmath298 s are words in @xmath146 in canonical form and the @xmath299 are expressions in @xmath271 for all @xmath217 .",
    "we perform a braid band move on the element @xmath300 and we obtain :    @xmath301{(\\pm)(p,1 ) } \\ t^p\\tau_2^{\\prime}\\cdot w_+\\sigma_1^{\\pm1},\\ ] ]    where @xmath302 is the same word as @xmath175 but with all indices shifted by one .",
    "hence , on the algebra level we have @xmath303 and @xmath304 .",
    "so :    @xmath305{(\\pm)(p,1 ) } \\ t^p\\tau_2^{\\prime}\\cdot \\sum_{i=1}^{n}{f_{i}(q)w_{i_+ } } g_1^{\\pm1}.\\ ] ]    on the other hand , for each mixed braid @xmath306 we also have :    @xmath307{(\\pm)(p,1)}\\ t^p\\tau_2^{\\prime}\\cdot w_{i_+ } \\sigma_1^{\\pm1}\\ \\forall\\ i,\\ ] ]    and thus , on the algebra level we finally obtain : @xmath308    that is , the following diagram commutes : @xmath309    see also figure  [ bbmskein ] . so the proof is concluded .",
    ".,width=432 ]    furthermore we have :    [ sprbbm ] the procedure of bringing a looping monomial in the @xmath86 s in the form of elements in the sets @xmath134 of theorem  2 is consistent with the braid band moves .",
    "let @xmath294 be an element in @xmath41 and @xmath310 the result of a performance of a _ bbm _ on @xmath294 .",
    "we now follow ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  2 & theorem  1 ) so as to order the indices of the monomials @xmath295 and @xmath311 in the @xmath86 s ( before and after the performance of the _ bbm _ ) .",
    "cabling the first moving strand coming from the performance of the _ bbm _ with the fixed strand of the mixed braid , and viewing this cable as one thickened strand , we have that the procedure we follow to order the indices of the @xmath86 s is identical before and after the performance of the _ bbm _ and this concludes the proof .",
    "using lemmas  [ artcomb ] , [ lbbmskein ] and [ sprbbm ] we now have the following :    ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  1)[bbms ] it suffices to consider the performance of braid band moves on the first strand of only elements in the set @xmath163 .    by the artin combing",

    "then , we order the indices of the monomials in the @xmath86 s before and after the performance of the _ bbm_. the result follows from lemma  [ sprbbm ]",
    ".      we shall now show that it suffices to perform _ bbm _",
    "s on elements in the linear bases @xmath171 of the algebras @xmath52 , which includes as a proper subset the basis @xmath4 of @xmath3 , described in   [ lamb ] .",
    "indeed , let @xmath317 as above . then , by ( 8) we have : @xmath318    see top row of fig .",

    "then , by theorem  5 : @xmath330    we conclude that :    @xmath331    the main ponts in the above procedure is that when performing a _ bbm _ , the looping generators @xmath61 ( in some @xmath122 ) remain formally the same ( in some @xmath332 ) .",
    "this implies that after the _ bbm _ and the cabling operation , the words @xmath84 and @xmath324 remain formally the same .",
    "furthermore , when converting the words @xmath319 and @xmath333 into linear sums of elements in the bases @xmath48 and @xmath334 respectively , the coefficients @xmath335 in @xmath336 remain the same .",
    "the above are summarized in the following proposition :    ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  2)[picprop2 ] the equations    @xmath337    result from equations of the form    @xmath338    where @xmath339 and @xmath340 .    .",
    ", width=211 ]      as mentioned in   2 ,",
    "a word in @xmath171 is a monomial in the @xmath61 s followed by a ` braiding tail ' , a monomial in the @xmath114 s .",
    "this ` braiding tail ' is a word in the algebra @xmath146 and the monomial in the @xmath61 s may have gaps in the indices . using the ordering relation given in definition  [ order ] and conjugation these gaps",
    "are managed by showing that a monomial in the @xmath61 s can be expressed as a sum of monomials in the @xmath61 s with consecutive indices , which are of less order than the initial word and which are followed by ` braiding tails ' ( theorem  8) .",
    "note that the exponents of the @xmath61 s are in general not ordered , so these end monomials do not necessarily belong to the basis @xmath4 of @xmath3 . in order to restrict the _ bbm _",
    "s only on elements in @xmath4 , we need first to augment the set @xmath4 .",
    "so , as a first step we consider the augmented set @xmath60 in @xmath3 that contains monomials in the @xmath61 s with consecutive indices but arbitrary exponents .",
    "note that , due to the presence of ` braiding tails ' , the set @xmath60 is considered as an @xmath146-module .",
    "we now proceed with showing that eqs  ( [ eq2 ] ) ( proposition  2 ) reduce to equations of the same type , but with elements in the set @xmath60 .",
    "for that , we need the following lemma about the monomial @xmath341 , which serves as the basis of the induction applied for proving the main result of this section , proposition  [ imp ] .",
    "* lemma  3)[gap ] the equations @xmath342 are equivalent to the equations @xmath343    indeed , in @xcite we prove that :    @xmath344    which captures the main idea of the proof of lemma  [ gap ] .    let now @xmath345 denote a word containing gaps in the ( ordered ) indices but not starting with a gap .",
    "when managing the gaps , the first part of the word ( before the first gap ) remains intact after managing the gaps and the same carries through after the performance of a _ bbm _ on the first moving strand .",
    "that is , the following diagram commutes : @xmath346 where @xmath347 and @xmath257 , for all @xmath217 .    in the case where the word @xmath347 starts with a gap , in @xcite",
    "it is shown that equations obtained from @xmath324 are equivalent to equations obtained from elements @xmath348 , where @xmath349 are monomials in the @xmath61 s _ not _ starting with a gap , _ but with the _ bbm _ performed on any strand _ ( see fig .  [ exgaps ] ) .",
    "the above are summarized in the following proposition :    ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  3)[imp ] in order to obtain an equivalent infinite system to the one obtained from elements in @xmath171 by performing braid band moves on the first moving strand , it suffices to consider monomials in @xmath60 followed by braiding tails in @xmath146 and perform braid band moves on any moving strand .",
    "the monomials in the @xmath61 s that we obtain after managing the gaps are not elements in the set @xmath4 , since the exponents of the loop generators are not necessarily ordered .",
    "we now order the exponents of the @xmath61 s and we show that equations obtained from elements in the @xmath146-module @xmath60 reduce to equations obtained from elements in the @xmath146-module @xmath4 .",
    "the procedure we follow is similar to the one described in @xcite , but , as we mentioned earlier , in this case we do it simultaneously before and after the performance of a _ bbm_.    ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  4 ) equations of the infinite system obtained from elements in @xmath60 followed by braiding tails in @xmath133 are equivalent to equations obtained from elements in @xmath4 followed by braiding tails , where a braid band move can be performed on any moving strand .",
    "it follows from theorem  9 , since all steps followed so as to order the exponents in a monomial in the @xmath61 s remain the same after the performance of a _ bbm _ , ignoring the @xmath350 appearing after the _",
    "bbm_.      we now deal with the ` braiding tails ' . applying the same technique as in theorem  10 before and after the performance of a _ bbm _ , we first prove that equations obtained by performing _",
    "s on any moving strand on elements in @xmath4 followed by words in @xmath146 , reduce to equations obtained by performing _",
    "s on any moving strand from elements in @xmath60 ( with no ` braiding tails ' ) .",
    "* proposition  5)[tailbbm ] equations obtained from _ bbm _",
    "s on elements in @xmath4 followed by words in @xmath146 are equivalent to equations obtained by performing a braid band move on any moving strand on elements in @xmath60 .",
    "we perform a _ bbm _ on an element @xmath351 in the @xmath146-module @xmath4 and we cable the parallel strand with the surgery strand , see figure  [ tailfig ] .",
    "we then apply theorem  10 before and after the performance of the _ bbm _ and uncable the parallel strand . the proof is illustrated in figure  [ tailfig ] .    . , width=518 ]    in this example we demonstrate proposition  [ tailbbm ] . @xmath352\\cdot t^3 & \\underset{bbm}{\\overset{1^{st } str.}{\\longrightarrow } } & \\left[q^2(q-1)(q^2-q+1)z^2\\right]\\cdot t^pt_1 ^ 3g_1^{\\pm1}\\\\ + & & + \\\\ a\\cdot",
    "t^2t_1 & \\underset{bbm}{\\overset{1^{st } str.}{\\longrightarrow } } & a\\cdot t^pt_1 ^ 2t_2g_1^{\\pm1}\\\\ \\end{matrix}\\ ] ] where @xmath353 .    in the process of eliminating the ` braiding tails '",
    "we have so far reached _ bbm _",
    "s in the set @xmath60 ( with no ` braiding tails ' ) .",
    "following the same procedure and applying the same techniques as in @xcite , we finally reach the set @xmath4 by means of the following :    ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  8) in order to obtain the _ bbm _ equations needed for computing the homflypt skein module of the lens spaces @xmath0 , it suffices to perform braid band moves on any strand on elements in the basis @xmath4 of @xmath3 .",
    "the proof is based on theorems  8 , 9 & 10 and the fact that the _ bbm _ s commute with the stabilization moves ( lemma  1 ) and the skein ( quadratic ) relation ( lemma  2 ) .",
    "the fact that the _ bbm _ s and conjugation do not commute , results in the need of performing braid band moves on all moving strands of elements in @xmath4 .     and on the @xmath354 strand of an element in @xmath4.,width=240 ]",
    "in this paper we present recent results toward the computation of the homflypt skein module of the lens spaces @xmath0 , @xmath290 , via braids .",
    "we first presented a new basis @xmath4 of @xmath3 in braid form , which is crucial for the braid approach to @xmath290 and we then related @xmath290 to @xmath3 by means of equations resulting from _ bbm _ s .",
    "in particular , we showed that by considering elements in the basis @xmath4 and imposing on values on them of the lambropoulou invariant @xmath2 for knots and links in st relations coming from the performance of _ bbm _",
    "s on all their moving strands , we arrive at an infinite system of equations , the solution of which coincides with the computation of @xmath290 .",
    "our results are summarized to the following :                                                        , skein module of links in a handlebody , _ topology 90 , proc . of the research semester in low dimensional topology at osu _ ,",
    "editors : b.apanasov , w.d.neumann , a.w.reid , l.siebenmann , de gruyter verlag ( 1992 ) , 315 - 342 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in this paper we present recent results toward the computation of the homflypt skein module of the lens spaces @xmath0 , @xmath1 , via braids . </S>",
    "<S> our starting point is the knot theory of the solid torus st and the lambropoulou invariant , @xmath2 , for knots and links in st , the universal analogue of the homflypt polynomial in st . </S>",
    "<S> the relation between @xmath1 and @xmath3 is established in @xcite and it is shown that in order to compute @xmath1 , it suffices to solve an infinite system of equations obtained by performing all possible braid band moves on elements in the basis of @xmath3 , @xmath4 , presented in @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> the solution of this infinite system of equations is very technical and is the subject of a sequel paper @xcite . </S>"
  ]
}
